description:
the libvirt version is 0.9.12-5 with debian patchs, and stable folsom nova.
"libvirtError: Timed out during operation: cannot acquire state change lock" was raised when I delete an instance, the strace log is:
2013-04-07 10:03:27 ERROR nova.openstack.common.rpc.amqp [-] Exception during message handling
2013-04-07 10:03:27 TRACE nova.openstack.common.rpc.amqp Traceback (most recent call last):
2013-04-07 10:03:27 TRACE nova.openstack.common.rpc.amqp   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/openstack/common/rpc/amqp.py", line 275, in _process_data

2013-04-07 10:03:27 TRACE nova.openstack.common.rpc.amqp   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/openstack/common/rpc/dispatcher.py", line 145, in dispatch
2013-04-07 10:03:27 TRACE nova.openstack.common.rpc.amqp     return getattr(proxyobj, method)(ctxt, **kwargs)
2013-04-07 10:03:27 TRACE nova.openstack.common.rpc.amqp   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/exception.py", line 117, in wrapped

2013-04-07 10:03:27 TRACE nova.openstack.common.rpc.amqp   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/compute/manager.py", line 325, in decorated_function

2013-04-07 10:03:27 TRACE nova.openstack.common.rpc.amqp     if ret == -1: raise libvirtError ('virDomainDestroy() failed', dom=self)
2013-04-07 10:03:27 TRACE nova.openstack.common.rpc.amqp libvirtError: Timed out during operation: cannot acquire state change lock
2013-04-07 10:03:27 TRACE nova.openstack.common.rpc.amqp

this instance can't be deleted with the same error even I deleted it several times and stick in deleting task_state, and then the fixed ip is used by another instance.
title: fixed ip re-used if instance can't be deleted with libvirtError raised

comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~hzwangpan

comments.content:
two questions:
1. how to deal with this exception of libvirt(I have run the periodic taskes in a stand alone process, may be a dead lock occurs in libvirt)?
2. should we release the fixed ip before instance is deleted?
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~hzwangpan

comments.content:
I have found the reason of the first question, it is because of qemu process is hung,
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=676205#c26
and this libvirtError is expected, we may need to catch and handle it.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~hzwangpan

comments.content: I do believe this is fixed in grizzly, please try with grizzly. If not please re-open this bug.

comments.content: Feel free to reopen if you're able to reproduce this with grizzly, or the latest code in master.  I'll set this bug as affecting folsom, though.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~russellb

comments.content: The grizzly code... and quite possibly folsom(although there are a few improvements around exceptions) seems to recover fine if libvirt is reachable. The question of what happens if libvirt (or any other virtualization system) is somewhat sticky though. You are right that comm failures with libvirt may happen for a variety of reasons. It seems the safest thing for nova to do is to do what it currently does, mark it as deleting in its task state to prevent anything other than a subsequent delete from running on the instance. Keeping it in task_state=deleting solves multiple issues:  it prevents duplicate quota adjustments from occurring in multiple delete requests (in case the first one fails for some reason); and perhaps even more importantly prevents another operation from being performed on an instance that is possibly in an inconsistent state. For example, depending on when and where things go wrong, the instance in libvirt may have been destroyed and undefined, but something happened to cause an exception to be returned to nova. We don't know immediately where things failed and we can't "assume" it is gone because we simply don't know. Until we can determine that the libvirt domain has been destroyed and undefined, anything that nova can reasonably do is some permutation of "keep it around until we can be sure it is dead".
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~beagles

comments.content:
Hi Brent,
I agree with you about keeping the instance at deleting task_state when exceptions raised in libvirt,
but my question or issue is that, the fixed ip belong to the deleting instance is released and reused by another new created instance, this may result in the ip can't be accessed, please see the log below:

comments.content: Please ignore comment #9 of mine, this bug is similar as it, but the commit of it doesn't handle the libvirt driver timeout exception, so a new commit is post.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~hzwangpan

comments.content:
Reviewed:  https://review.openstack.org/32841
Committed: http://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/d925044e09509495e7474d5f625bbd45d8985afa
Submitter: Jenkins
Branch:    master

commit d925044e09509495e7474d5f625bbd45d8985afa
Author: Wangpan <email address hidden>
Date:   Thu Jun 13 15:19:21 2013 +0800

    Don't deallocate network if destroy time out
    
    Fixes bug #1169057
    Sames as bug 1180178, if libvirt returns time out error during destroy
    an instance, we also can't deallocate the network of the instance,
    otherwise the fixed ip of it may be re-used by another new instance,
    and resulted in the new instance can't be accessed by the fixed ip.
    
    Change-Id: I04dfd21bb1b7168abc71f39e836126a11dad6d8d
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~hudson-openstack

comments.content:
Fix proposed to branch: stable/grizzly
Review: https://review.openstack.org/36575

Author: Wangpan <email address hidden>

    Don't deallocate network if destroy time out
    
    Fixes bug #1169057
    Sames as bug 1180178, if libvirt returns time out error during destroy
    an instance, we also can't deallocate the network of the instance,
    otherwise the fixed ip of it may be re-used by another new instance,
    and resulted in the new instance can't be accessed by the fixed ip.
    
    Change-Id: I04dfd21bb1b7168abc71f39e836126a11dad6d8d
    (cherry picked from commit d925044e09509495e7474d5f625bbd45d8985afa)
